node.title: Compiling MOOSE application with static linking
node.bodyText:
Dear developers and users,
We need to produce an executable for our MOOSE application that is linked static (not dynamic). I tried adapting LDFLAGS
(export LDFLAGS="-static $LDFLAGS") but it didn't produce a statically linked executable.
Is there  a way to do this in your experience?
Many thanks in advance
@milljm
@permcody

You might need to specify --enable-static too?  I've never used static linking myself, and I'm not sure how we propagate the options down to dependencies, but it looks like --enable-all-static is a libMesh-specific thing that TIMPI might be ignoring, whereas --enable-static is a libtool standard option.

That did the trick. Thanks @roystgnr
I edited my original response to include the additional switch.
Thank you very much @milljm @roystgnr

node.title: git-clang-format not in the moose environment.
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone.
I noticed that the 'git-clang-format' command/executable/script is no long in the moose environment.
I just installed a fresh environment using the instructions from here and I do not get git-clang-format.
Is this expected ? if this is, should I change the script install_format_hook.sh to reflect this ?
Thank you in advance for any pointers.
@milljm

It looks like this may have been dropped when we became very strict in our moose-mpich package building process. You should be able to install the clang format tools by doing the following while inside the moose Conda environment:
mamba install clangdev
I'll see about getting this package back into mix when installing moose-mpich.

Correction, I think the least amount of packages to get clang-format working is by installing the following:
mamba install clang-tools
I'll leave the original clangdev in case clang-tools ends up not working. I came back to edit, because I am testing these package installations on a Linux machine (which we use GCC and not LLVM). By installing clangdev, a person will actually get a clang compiler. Something that you may not want/need on a Linux machine. However, I will state that by having clangdev installed... everything seems to still work fine.
Creating a PR to address this: #22420
Thank you for the clarification and a quick PR.  Looking forward to use the pre commit hook again !

node.title: Set two ThinLayerHeatTransfers on one interface
node.bodyText: There are two very thin layers of oxide on my solid-liquid interface, with a thickness of 10 μm. So I want to use ThinLayerHeatTransfer at the interface to simulate the effect of these two oxide layers on the deterioration of heat transfer. But on an interface, it seems like I can only set up a ThinLayerHeatTransfer. Because only one material can be set on the interface boundary. What is the way MOOSE can set up two ThinLayerHeatTransfers on an interface?

I do not think the current ThinLayerHeatTransfer implementation can be used to model two layers. Two options:

homogenize the two layers into one and use the ThinLayerHeatTransfer
follow the theory as described on ThinLayerHeatTransfer documentation, extend it to support two layers.
I think the first way is easier to implement and I will take it. Thank you!

In my model, the temperature variable for the solid region is Ts and the temperature variable for the fluid region is Tf. If I want to set ThinLayerHeatTransfer on the solid-fluid interface, should I set Ts to variable and Tf to neighbor_var? Just like this:
  [magnetite]
    type = ThinLayerHeatTransfer
    thermal_conductivity = k_magnetite
    specific_heat = cp_magnetite
    density = rho_magnetite
    thickness = 1e-3 # 10μm
    variable = Ts
    neighbor_var = Tf
    boundary = solid_wall
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []

I set Ts to both variable and neighbor_var before, but it turns out ThinLayerHeatTransfer doesn't work.

Could you attach your complete input file or a simpler version?
To use the ThinLayerHeatTransfer, you have to use BreakMeshByBlockGenerator to create the interface. Take a look at this example, (modules/heat_conduction/test/tests/thin_layer_heat_transfer/transient_2d.i)

I've read the input file, but it is a little different from my case. I use gmsh to generate mesh file, and my solid area and fluid area share an interface. Do I still need to use BreakMeshByBlockGenerator in this case?
Here is my input file:
# Units: specific_heat_capacity--cp--J/(kg.K); density--rho--kg/(cm^3);
# dynamic_viscosity--mu--kg/(cm.s); thermal_conductivity--k--W/(cm.K);
# pressure--kg/(cm.s^2); force--kg.cm/s^2

outlet_pressure = 0
inlet_velocity = 150 # cm/s
ini_temp = 593 # K

[Mesh]
  file = '2layers_2d_midline.msh'
[]

[Variables]
  [velocity]
    family = LAGRANGE_VEC
    order = FIRST
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [p]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [Tf]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [Ts]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    block = 'solid'
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [power]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = FIRST
    block = 'solid'
  []
[]

[ICs]
  [initial_velocity]
    type = VectorConstantIC
    variable = velocity
    x_value = 0
    y_value = ${inlet_velocity}
    z_value = 0
  []
  [initial_p]
    type = FunctionIC
    variable = p
    function = ini_p
  []
  [initial_Tf]
    type = ConstantIC
    variable = Tf
    value = ${ini_temp}
  []
  [initial_Ts]
    type = ConstantIC
    variable = Ts
    value = ${ini_temp}
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [fluid_mass]
    type = INSADMass
    variable = p
  []
  [fluid_mass_pspg]
    type = INSADMassPSPG
    variable = p
  []
  [fluid_momentum_time]
    type = INSADMomentumTimeDerivative
    variable = velocity
  []
  [fluid_momentum_convection]
    type = INSADMomentumAdvection
    variable = velocity
  []
  [fluid_momentum_viscous]
    type = INSADMomentumViscous
    variable = velocity
  []
  [fluid_momentum_pressure]
    type = INSADMomentumPressure
    variable = velocity
    pressure = p
    integrate_p_by_parts = true
  []
  [fluid_momentum_supg]
    type = INSADMomentumSUPG
    variable = velocity
    velocity = velocity
  []
  [fluid_temperature_time]
    type = INSADHeatConductionTimeDerivative
    variable = Tf
  []
  [fluid_temperature_conduction]
    type = ADHeatConduction
    variable = Tf
    thermal_conductivity = 'k'
  []
  [fluid_temperature_advection]
    type = INSADEnergyAdvection
    variable = Tf
  []
  [fluid_temperature_supg]
    type = INSADEnergySUPG
    variable = Tf
    velocity = velocity
  []

  [solid_temperature_time]
    type = ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative
    variable = Ts
    density_name = 'rho'
    specific_heat = 'cp'
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [solid_temperature_conduction]
    type = ADHeatConduction
    variable = Ts
    thermal_conductivity = 'k'
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [heat_source]
    type = ADCoupledForce
    variable = Ts
    v = power
    block = 'solid'
  []
[]

[InterfaceKernels]
  [convection_heat_transfer]
    type = ConjugateHeatTransfer
    variable = Tf
    T_fluid = Tf
    neighbor_var = 'Ts'
    boundary = 'solid_wall'
    htc = 'htc'
  []
  [magnetite]
    type = ThinLayerHeatTransfer
    thermal_conductivity = k_magnetite
    specific_heat = cp_magnetite
    density = rho_magnetite
    thickness = 1e-1
    variable = Ts
    neighbor_var = Ts
    boundary = solid_wall
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [power_distribution_auxk]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = power
    function = power_distribution_function
    block = 'solid'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [no_slip]
    type = VectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'solid_wall'
  []
  [inlet_velocity]
    type = VectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'fluid_bottom'
    function_y = ${inlet_velocity}
  []
  [symmetry]
    type = ADVectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'fluid_wall'
    function_x = 0
    set_x_comp = true
    set_y_comp = false
    set_z_comp = false
  []
  [outlet_p]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = p
    boundary = 'fluid_top'
    value = ${outlet_pressure}
  []
  [inlet_T]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = Tf
    boundary = 'fluid_bottom'
    value = ${ini_temp}
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [solid_constant_mat]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'k cp rho'
    prop_values = '0.06 300 0.010000'
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [magnetite_constant_mat]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'k_magnetite cp_magnetite rho_magnetite'
    prop_values = '0.02 200 0.005000'
    boundary = 'solid_wall'
  []
  [fluid_constant_mat]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'k cp rho mu'
    prop_values = '0.30 145 0.007000 2e-5'
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [ins_fluid_mat]
    type = INSADStabilized3Eqn
    velocity = velocity
    pressure = p
    temperature = Tf
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [htc_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    f_name = htc
    function = '5'
    boundary = solid_wall
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [ini_p]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '0.010302 * 981 * (10 - y)'
  []
  [power_distribution_function]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '300 * sin(pi * y / 10)'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  dt = 1
  end_time = 100
  steady_state_detection = true

  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason -snes_linesearch_monitor'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       NONZERO'
  line_search = 'none'

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8
  nl_max_its = 30
  l_max_its = 100
  automatic_scaling = true
  compute_scaling_once = false
  off_diagonals_in_auto_scaling = true
[]

[Outputs]
  perf_graph = true
  print_linear_residuals = true
  exodus = true
  csv = true
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [average_solid_Ts]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = Ts
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [average_fluid_Tf]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = Tf
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [max_solid_Ts]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = Ts
    value_type = max
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [max_fluid_Tf]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = Tf
    value_type = max
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [min_solid_Ts]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = Ts
    value_type = min
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [min_fluid_Tf]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = Tf
    value_type = min
    block = 'fluid'
  []
[]

[Debug]
  show_var_residual_norms = true
[]

2layers_2d_midline.zip
I set Ts to both variable and neighbor_var. But I get the same result whether I comment out the [magnetite] block or not.

Now there are two problems. The first is that neighbor_var seems to be Tf, not Ts. Because at the solid-fluid interface, one side of the thin layer transfers heat with the solid, and the other side transfers heat with the fluid. The second is that when I add a thin layer to the fluid-solid interface (the thermal conductivity of the thin layer is much smaller than that of the solid), the heat transfer between the solid and the liquid is deteriorated. The maximum temperature of the solid should be higher after adding the thin layer. But the simulation results are the opposite. After adding the thin layer, the maximum temperature of the solid decreases. Here are some output files and a finer mesh.
2layers_2d_midline.zip
no_thin_layer.zip
thin_layer_0.1.zip

Yes, you need to start with a continuous mesh and then use BreakMeshByBlockGenerator to create the interface internally by MOOSE.
I saw your have both ConjugateHeatTransfer and ThinLayerHeatTransfer applied on the same interface. Do you need both?
Do you really need two temperature variables, i.e., Ts and Tf? Would one T variable work?

I think more about it. The ThinLayerHeatTransfer does not support two different variables as for now. Thus, I made some changes in your input file. You can try it using the mesh you provided in 'no_thin_layer' folder. I do not know your problem well, so I cannot tell whether the results look reasonable or not. Let me know your thoughts.
# Units: specific_heat_capacity--cp--J/(kg.K); density--rho--kg/(cm^3);
# dynamic_viscosity--mu--kg/(cm.s); thermal_conductivity--k--W/(cm.K);
# pressure--kg/(cm.s^2); force--kg.cm/s^2

outlet_pressure = 0
inlet_velocity = 150 # cm/s
ini_temp = 593 # K

[Mesh]
  [file_mesh]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = 'no_thin_layer.e'
  []
  [breakmesh]
    input = file_mesh
    type = BreakMeshByBlockGenerator
    block_pairs = 'fluid solid'
    split_interface = true
    add_interface_on_two_sides = true
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [velocity]
    family = LAGRANGE_VEC
    order = FIRST
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [p]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [T]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [power]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = FIRST
    block = 'solid'
  []
[]

[ICs]
  [initial_velocity]
    type = VectorConstantIC
    variable = velocity
    x_value = 0
    y_value = ${inlet_velocity}
    z_value = 0
  []
  [initial_p]
    type = FunctionIC
    variable = p
    function = ini_p
  []
  [initial_Tf]
    type = ConstantIC
    variable = T
    value = ${ini_temp}
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [initial_Ts]
    type = ConstantIC
    variable = T
    value = ${ini_temp}
    block = 'solid'
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [fluid_mass]
    type = INSADMass
    variable = p
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [fluid_mass_pspg]
    type = INSADMassPSPG
    variable = p
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [fluid_momentum_time]
    type = INSADMomentumTimeDerivative
    variable = velocity
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [fluid_momentum_convection]
    type = INSADMomentumAdvection
    variable = velocity
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [fluid_momentum_viscous]
    type = INSADMomentumViscous
    variable = velocity
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [fluid_momentum_pressure]
    type = INSADMomentumPressure
    variable = velocity
    pressure = p
    integrate_p_by_parts = true
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [fluid_momentum_supg]
    type = INSADMomentumSUPG
    variable = velocity
    velocity = velocity
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [fluid_temperature_time]
    type = INSADHeatConductionTimeDerivative
    variable = T
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [fluid_temperature_conduction]
    type = ADHeatConduction
    variable = T
    thermal_conductivity = 'k'
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [fluid_temperature_advection]
    type = INSADEnergyAdvection
    variable = T
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [fluid_temperature_supg]
    type = INSADEnergySUPG
    variable = T
    velocity = velocity
    block = 'fluid'
  []

  [solid_temperature_time]
    type = ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative
    variable = T
    density_name = 'rho'
    specific_heat = 'cp'
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [solid_temperature_conduction]
    type = ADHeatConduction
    variable = T
    thermal_conductivity = 'k'
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [heat_source]
    type = ADCoupledForce
    variable = T
    v = power
    block = 'solid'
  []
[]

[InterfaceKernels]
  [magnetite]
    type = ThinLayerHeatTransfer
    thermal_conductivity = k_magnetite
    specific_heat = cp_magnetite
    density = rho_magnetite
    thickness = 1e-1
    variable = T
    neighbor_var = T
    boundary = solid_fluid
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [power_distribution_auxk]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = power
    function = power_distribution_function
    block = 'solid'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [no_slip]
    type = VectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'solid_wall'
  []
  [inlet_velocity]
    type = VectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'fluid_bottom'
    function_y = ${inlet_velocity}
  []
  [symmetry]
    type = ADVectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'fluid_wall'
    function_x = 0
    set_x_comp = true
    set_y_comp = false
    set_z_comp = false
  []
  [outlet_p]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = p
    boundary = 'fluid_top'
    value = ${outlet_pressure}
  []
  [inlet_T]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = T
    boundary = 'fluid_bottom'
    value = ${ini_temp}
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [solid_constant_mat]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'k cp rho'
    prop_values = '0.06 300 0.010000'
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [magnetite_constant_mat]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'k_magnetite cp_magnetite rho_magnetite'
    prop_values = '0.02 200 0.005000'
    boundary = 'solid_fluid'
  []
  [fluid_constant_mat]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'k cp rho mu'
    prop_values = '0.30 145 0.007000 2e-5'
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [ins_fluid_mat]
    type = INSADStabilized3Eqn
    velocity = velocity
    pressure = p
    temperature = T
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [htc_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    f_name = htc
    function = '5'
    boundary = solid_wall
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [ini_p]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '0.010302 * 981 * (10 - y)'
  []
  [power_distribution_function]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '300 * sin(pi * y / 10)'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  dt = 1
  end_time = 100
  steady_state_detection = true

  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason -snes_linesearch_monitor'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       NONZERO'
  line_search = 'none'

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8
  nl_max_its = 30
  l_max_its = 100
  automatic_scaling = true
  compute_scaling_once = false
  off_diagonals_in_auto_scaling = true
[]

[Outputs]
  perf_graph = true
  print_linear_residuals = true
  exodus = true
  csv = true
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [average_solid_T]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = T
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [average_fluid_T]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = T
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [max_solid_T]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = T
    value_type = max
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [max_fluid_T]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = T
    value_type = max
    block = 'fluid'
  []
  [min_solid_T]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = T
    value_type = min
    block = 'solid'
  []
  [min_fluid_T]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = T
    value_type = min
    block = 'fluid'
  []
[]

[Debug]
  show_var_residual_norms = true
[]

I saw your have both ConjugateHeatTransfer and ThinLayerHeatTransfer applied on the same interface. Do you need both?

To put it simply, I want to model fluid-solid conjugate heat transfer, where the solid is a heat source. During the flow process, the solid surface will be fouled, so a thin layer needs to be added to the fluid-solid interface to represent the thermal resistance caused by fouling.

Do you really need two temperature variables, i.e., Ts and Tf? Would one T variable work?

I think it is necessary to set the temperature variable separately in the fluid and solid areas. I used to set the temperature to T in both the solid and fluid regions, but it turned out that no matter what the htc was equal to, the answer I calculated would be the same.

node.title: Generic Material property based on Damage Evolution
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I’m trying to implement the damage evolution shown below as a material property so that another material can call the damage variable (for example, as a damage index). Can anyone recommend an example MOOSE file in this regard? How can I approach this? Thank you.

Hello
You should be able to make a new material property for this.
If you follow the tutorial we do introduce material properties there with an example
What dimension is this quantity? It's a scalar right?
Guillaume
Thanks, Guillaume. The damage variable is a scalar quantity and it evolves with time.
ok a regular material property (type Real) should be appropriate then.

Hello @GiudGiud,
When developing a material property, do you always have to inherit from the material class? Or can you inherit from a different class and compute your _qp properties? For example, I inherited from a “radialreturncreepstressupdate” class because it will enable me to apply the newton iteration to compute my damage variable. However, when I tried using the computeQpProperties method, I got the following Error shown below. (P/S: I attached the files below).

damageEvol.zip

Hello
Yes you have to at some level. You can inherit from a child of the material class though.
It works here, radialreturncreepstressupdate inherits from RadialReturnStressUpdate, which inherits from StressUpdateBase, which inherits from Material.
From the errors it looks like you should be writing HLDamageEvoleTempl<is_ad> (with is_ad = true or false depending on whether you are using AD).
I think the problem is that you are inheriting from RadialReturnCreepStressUpdateBaseTempl instead of ADRadialReturnCreepStressUpdateBase, which is the instantiation of that template.
Or is this on purpose? Do you want to be creating a new template or a new class?
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud,
Thanks. I’m creating a material class (not a template) with a damaged property defined at the _qp points so that another material object may call this _qp damaged property. I added  template <bool is_ad> on top the definition of the computeQpProperties() method, and it seems to be working now except for one error (shown below).
The error indicated that ‘scalar’ (which is computed within another method in the class) could not be used in the ‘computeQpProperties()’ method without first declaring it. How do I declare it so I can use it to compute the final state of my damaged property?  (P/S: In case you want to see the files, it is attached to my previous question).
you need to make scalar (call it _scalar instead) a class attribute. You define it in the header as a part of the class, then each routine may use the value and modify it too

Hi @GiudGiud,
It didn’t work. However, it worked when I defined my own method/function (without overriding the computeQpProperties method) and declared scalar. I’m not entirely sure. Is this a good code development? Do you think the damage variable is computed successfully as _qp properties? And do you think the scalar obtained from the previous methods is successfully used in this new method/function? See attached for the files
damageEvol.zip

If you do not override computeQpProperties you are not computing the property, this is clear.
So no I do not think it s computed successfully.
I do not see _scalar as a class attribute in your input.
Should the scalar be a material property instead? What does it represent?

Hi @GiudGiud,
So basically, I’m setting up the damage evolution as a residual equation to be computed by newton iteration using the “computeResidualInternal” and “computeDerivative” methods (similar to what is done in the IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate or PowerLawCreepStressUpdate classes). The scalar is the damage increment (i.e., d \Delta D), which will come (out) from these methods.

Hi @GiudGiud, I believe I finally found a way to update the damage variable with the scalar value. I overrode the iterationFinalize() method (which is inherited from the radialreturnstressupdate class), and it compiled successfully. What do you think?
damageEvol.zip

@batodon if you want to explicitly update a material property in time, you can "declare" the material property and "get" the old material property in a material class, then you implement an explicit Euler update in computeQpProperties.
You can see a slightly complicated example here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/materials/ComputeCrystalPlasticityStressDamage.C
See the variables:
_plastic_work
_plastic_work_old
that I am using for updating the plastic work in a plasticity model using:
_plastic_work[_qp] = _plastic_work_old[_qp] + variation_of_plastic_work
You can use the variable _dt for the timestep
Nicolò
Thanks a lot, @ngrilli. This lead was very helpful!

node.title: Question about updating boundary conditions each time step (depends on time history)
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose community,
I'm new to moose. We would like to implement dynamics rupture earthquake problem. The geometry setup is two rectangular blocks with the bottom boundary of upper block and the top boundary of lower block are considered as fault surface.
At the current point, we are able to

solve the dynamic FEM problem using "TensorMechanics" "CentralDifference" to get displacement.
extract the displacement on the two fault surfaces mentioned above as "AuxVariable" using "AuxKernel" restricted at those surfaces.

Now we would like to do some multiplications with the data on the surfaces(to ensure continuity conditions, which could be done pointwise), and feed the post-computed displacements as boundary condition, then apply on the weak form and solve the system again for the next time step.
I'm wondering which would be the better approach for this. Any help would be appreciated! Thanks!

Hello
are you going to be solving this boundary condition implicitly? Or is that part of the system going to be explicit
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thanks for your reply. So the system solve is going to be explicit. After getting solution at two surfaces as auxvariable (displacement), for the update of boundary condition, we may experience both situations depend on the model we use:
Slip weakening: the new BC will be calculated explicitly
Rate-and-State Friction: a nonlinear equation using Newton Raphson is needed to be solve.
For both situations, each point has its own set of equation, there is no explicit dependence among different points.
Thanks,
Chunhui
Does the BC depend only on local dofs? Or does it have some sort of extended stencil (on the BC sideset, or across the fault?)
It only depends on local dofs

I think you should be able to place all your code in a boundary condition then.
The two situations could be determined there

So the current issue we have, due to the limit knowledge of moose, is that we are not sure how to pass a set of aux values into "Function", which then gives an input (as a Function object) for "FunctionDirichletBC" or "FunctionNeumannBC". It would be better if you could direct us to some examples.
Or you mean "Custom Boundary Conditions" in https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/examples/ex04_bcs.html ?

look at coupled BCs to add in varaible dependence
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/bcs/CoupledVarNeumannBC.C
Functions do not depend on variables so it's not what you want
this example in the tutorial you linked to seems pretty good for what you want to do
Thanks, I'm looking into it.

Hi Guillaume, I think the path you directed is promising. Another question is how should we compute elastic forces, basically <stress(displacement), grad(test function)> that is evaluated in the "StressDivergenceTensors" kernel when solving the system, I will need to feed this into Custom Boundary Condition as well. Thanks!

node.title: Troublesshooting: Build Issues
node.bodyText:
hello everyone, I have some problems.
After the moose is installed, some errors occurs when I "make - j 4".  Plaese see the below picture:

Then, I found answer in the Troublesshooting: Build Issues, when I "git fetch upstream",the fatals is :

Now, what should I do?
Thanks for your help！

Hello
your upstream is probably called origin because you did not rename it.
so type git fetch origin instead
Guillaume

hello,Thanks for your help!
Now,I encountered a new problem, as shown in the figure below：
you dont need to init submodules. large_media is only for building the documentation locally and getting the pictures
However, compilation errors are consistent, as shown in the following figure：

what s the commit number?
are you using the conda installation path?
what is the output of the diagnostics script in moose/scripts

About commit number, When I type “make -j 4”, errors are reported.
The installation path is completely in accordance with the installation guidelines
There is no "nohup.out" file.

the commit number is the output of git show not make
which guidelines? there are more than one way to install the code
it's not the nohup file I'd like to see, please run the diagnostics.sh script in moose/scripts

About guidelines,Refer to the following link “https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html”.
The files generated after running diagnostics.sh are as follows：
nohup.txt

You have another compiler installed that is hiding the compilers we are installing with conda
/home/yydeng/intel/compilers_and_libraries_2019.5.281/linux/mpi/intel64/bin/mpicc
Are you setting environment variables to find that compiler? Did you add it to your PATH for example?
You need to let the CC, FC, CXX environment variables point to the compilers installed by conda as well

node.title: Loading solutions from two different exodus files
node.bodyText:
Is it possible to load in two exodus files (say A.e and B.e) and take
var1 var2 var3 from A.e
var4 var5 var6 from B.e as an initial condition (using restart)
?

Hello
not directly. But you can do it with a multiapps and transfer the initialized quantities
Guillaume
I guess alternatively you can add as many SolutionUserobjects as you want... Then use SolutionAux to initialize these variables at INITIAL.

node.title: Integrating moose based app into our online calculation platform
node.bodyText:
Hello Moose Team,
We are currently developing an online calculation website which consists of several models developed by our research team. The website is nonprofitable platform, which is open to everyone to access and do the calculation with the model we provide. Because Moose is an open-source code, we are considering to build one of our model with Moose and integrate it to our platform. We want to know if this is under the permission of the Moose license?
Thank you!

@friedmud
Yes, LGPL 2.1 will allow that
Thank you. Another question, are we obliged to make our app code open source too?

LGPL does not enforce that.
it s the straight GPL that does that.
OK, Thank you!

Hello
This is indeed the problem, you need to update libmesh.
Maybe there is a LIBMESH_DIR variable set that is preventing finidng the new version?
Can you remove moose/libmesh then try to update again?
what does echo $LIBMESH_DIR return?
Guillaume

no this is very problematic.
You can either have libmesh ithrough conda or through a manual install with the update_and_rebuild script not both
If you want to use conda, just mamba update --all
Is there anyway to remove the libmesh installed by update_and_rebuild?
rm moose/libmesh -rf
I have performed this and mamba update --all and still get the same errors when I make -j8, even after a clobberall

ok then your mamba is not updating properly
this can happen as dependency resolution can prevent updates.
Unless mamba list shows you have a libmesh from September, I would remove the conda environment and re-install it
Yeah my mamba wasn't updating the libmesh version for some reason, removing the environment and recreating it has fixed the issue. Thanks for the help!

node.title: solution type
node.bodyText:
I would like to know whether the expression of the solution is of nodal or modal type. With my current knowledge of the code, I think the type of the variable in the configuration file is nodal when set to lagrange and modal when set to monomial. I don't know if I understand this correctly. Is there a specific document that says something about nodal
representation and modal representation?

Hello
There's a lot of finite element families supported and whether a variable is 'nodal' or 'elemental' isnt always the best description as a variable can have degrees of freedom on both nodes and elements (especially as libmesh often stores shared dofs whether nodal, edge or face-based dofs, on the nodes).
I dont think we have a documentation page on all the families supported. There's an enum there:
https://libmesh.github.io/doxygen/namespacelibMesh.html#abcdbcd8364bf9fb7a67b3b4013031b2d
The nodal ones are lagrange and hierarchic iirc.
Within the code, you can perform a call to var->isNodal() (from a MooseVariable* pointer) to see if a variable is nodal
Guillaume
